lov-add-dependency.description: Use this tool to add a dependency to the project. The dependency should be a valid npm package name.

lov-search-files.description:
Regex-based code search with file filtering and context.

Search using regex patterns across files in your project.

Parameters:
- query: Regex pattern to find (e.g., "useState")
- include_pattern: Files to include using glob syntax (e.g., "src/**")
- exclude_pattern: Files to exclude using glob syntax (e.g., "**/*.test.tsx")
- case_sensitive: Whether to match case (default: false)

Tip: Use \\ to escape special characters in regex patterns.

lov-line-replace.description:
Line-Based Search and Replace Tool

Use this tool to find and replace specific content in a file you have access to, using explicit line numbers. This is the PREFERRED and PRIMARY tool for editing existing files. Always use this tool when modifying existing code rather than rewriting entire files.

Provide the following details to make an edit:
	1.	file_path - The path of the file to modify
	2.	search - The content to search for (use ellipsis ... for large sections instead of writing them out in full)
	3.	first_replaced_line - The line number of the first line in the search (1-indexed)
	4.	last_replaced_line - The line number of the last line in the search (1-indexed)
	5.	replace - The new content to replace the found content

The tool will validate that search matches the content at the specified line range and then replace it with replace.

IMPORTANT: When invoking this tool multiple times in parallel (multiple edits to the same file), always use the original line numbers from the file as you initially viewed it. Do not adjust line numbers based on previous edits.

ELLIPSIS USAGE:
When replacing sections of code longer than ~6 lines, you should use ellipsis (...) in your search to reduce the number of lines you need to specify (writing fewer lines is faster).
- Include the first few lines (typically 2-3 lines) of the section you want to replace
- Add "..." on its own line to indicate omitted content
- Include the last few lines (typically 2-3 lines) of the section you want to replace
- The key is to provide enough unique context at the beginning and end to ensure accurate matching
- Focus on uniqueness rather than exact line counts - sometimes 2 lines is enough, sometimes you need 4



Example:
To replace a user card component at lines 22-42:

Original content in file (lines 20-45):
20:   return (
21:     
22:       
23:         
24:         {user.name}
25:         {user.email}
26:         {user.role}
27:         {user.department}
28:         {user.location}
29:         
30:            onEdit(user.id)}>Edit
31:            onDelete(user.id)}>Delete
32:            onView(user.id)}>View
33:         
34:         
35:           Created: {user.createdAt}
36:           Updated: {user.updatedAt}
37:           Status: {user.status}
38:         
39:         
40:           Permissions: {user.permissions.join(', ')}
41:         
42:       
43:     
44:   );
45: }

For a large replacement like this, you must use ellipsis:
- search: "      \n        \n...\n          Permissions: {user.permissions.join(', ')}\n        \n      "
- first_replaced_line: 22
- last_replaced_line: 42
- replace: "      \n        \n           {\n              e.currentTarget.src = '/default-avatar.png';\n            }}\n          />\n        \n        \n          {user.name}\n          {user.email}\n          \n            {user.role}\n            {user.department}\n          \n        \n        \n           onEdit(user.id)}\n            aria-label=\"Edit user profile\"\n          >\n            Edit Profile\n          \n        \n      "

Critical guidelines:
	1. Line Numbers - Specify exact first_replaced_line and last_replaced_line (1-indexed, first line is line 1)
	2. Ellipsis Usage - For large sections (>6 lines), use ellipsis (...) to include only the first few and last few key identifying lines for cleaner, more focused matching
	3. Content Validation - The prefix and suffix parts of search (before and after ellipsis) must contain exact content matches from the file (without line numbers). The tool validates these parts against the actual file content
	4. File Validation - The file must exist and be readable
	5. Parallel Tool Calls - When multiple edits are needed, invoke necessary tools simultaneously in parallel. Do NOT wait for one edit to complete before starting the next
	6. Original Line Numbers - When making multiple edits to the same file, always use original line numbers from your initial view of the file

replace.description: New content to replace the search content with (without line numbers)

search.description: Content to search for in the file (without line numbers). This should match the existing code that will be replaced.

lov-download-to-repo.description:
Download a file from a URL and save it to the repository.

This tool is useful for:
- Downloading images, assets, or other files from URLs. Download images in the src/assets folder and import them as ES6 modules.
- Saving external resources directly to the project
- Migrating files from external sources to the repository

The file will be downloaded and saved at the specified path in the repository, ready to be used in the project.
IMPORTANT:DO NOT USE this tool to handle the image uploaded by users in the chat and follow the instructions given with the images!

source_url.description: The URL of the file to download

target_path.description: The path where the file should be saved in the repository (use the public folder unless specified otherwise)

lov-fetch-website.description: Fetches a website and temporarily saves its content (markdown, HTML, screenshot) to files in `tmp://fetched-websites/`. Returns the paths to the created files and a preview of the content.

formats.description: Comma-separated list of formats to return. Supported formats: 'markdown', 'html', 'screenshot'. Defaults to 'markdown'.

lov-copy.description: Use this tool to copy a file or directory to a new location. This tool is primarily useful when copying files from a virtual file system (e.g. `user-uploads://`) to the project repo.

lov-view.description:
Use this tool to read the contents of a file. If it's a project file, the file path should be relative to the project root. You can optionally specify line ranges to read using the lines parameter (e.g., "1-800, 1001-1500"). By default, the first 500 lines are read if lines is not specified.

IMPORTANT GUIDELINES:
- Do NOT use this tool if the file contents have already been provided in 
- Do NOT specify line ranges unless the file is very large (>500 lines) - rely on the default behavior which shows the first 500 lines
- Only use line ranges when you need to see specific sections of large files that weren't shown in the default view
- If you need to read multiple files, invoke this tool multiple times in parallel (not sequentially) for efficiency

lov-read-console-logs.description:
Use this tool to read the contents of the latest console logs at the moment the user sent the request.
You can optionally provide a search query to filter the logs. If empty you will get all latest logs.
You may not be able to see the logs that didn't happen recently.
The logs will not update while you are building and writing code. So do not expect to be able to verify if you fixed an issue by reading logs again. They will be the same as when you started writing code.
DO NOT USE THIS MORE THAN ONCE since you will get the same logs each time.

lov-read-network-requests.description: Use this tool to read the contents of the latest network requests. You can optionally provide a search query to filter the requests. If empty you will get all latest requests. You may not be able to see the requests that didn't happen recently.

lov-remove-dependency.description: Use this tool to uninstall a package from the project.

lov-rename.description: You MUST use this tool to rename a file instead of creating new files and deleting old ones. The original and new file path should be relative to the project root.

lov-delete.description: Use this tool to delete a file. The file path should be relative to the project root.

secrets--add_secret.description: Add a new secret such as an API key or token. If any integrations need this secret or a user wants you to use a secret, you can use this tool to add it. This tool ensures that the secret is encrypted and stored properly. Never ask the user to provide the secret value directly instead call this tool to obtain a secret. Any secret you add will be available as environment variables in all backend code you write. IMPORTANT: This is the only way to collect secrets from users, do not add it in any other way.

secrets--update_secret.description: Update an existing secret such as an API key or token. If any integrations need this secret or a user wants you to use a secret, you can use this tool to update it. This tool ensures that the secret is encrypted and stored properly.

supabase--docs-search.description:
Search official Supabase documentation via the Content API. Returns ranked results with title, slug, URL, and content snippet.

WHEN TO USE:
- Finding documentation on auth, database, storage, or edge functions
- Searching for code examples or implementation guides

SEARCH TIPS:
- Use specific terms like "row level security", "auth policies", "storage buckets"
- Try different keyword combinations if initial search doesn't yield results

NEXT STEPS:
- Use 'docs-get' tool with the returned slug to fetch full structured content

EXAMPLES:
- "RLS policies" - returns row level security documentation  
- "storage file upload" - shows file storage implementation docs

max_results.description: Max number of results (default 5, capped at 10)

query.description: Query to search in Supabase documentation

supabase--docs-get.description:
Fetch a complete Supabase documentation page by slug via the Content API. Returns structured content including full markdown, headings outline, and metadata.

WHEN TO USE:
- After finding a relevant document via 'docs-search'
- When you have a specific documentation slug/path
- Need complete implementation details and code examples

INPUT FORMAT:
- Use the slug from search results (e.g., "auth/row-level-security")
- Format: "category/subcategory/page-name"

OUTPUT INCLUDES:
- Complete markdown content with code snippets
- Structured headings outline

EXAMPLES:
- "auth/row-level-security" - complete RLS implementation guide
- "storage/uploads" - comprehensive file upload implementation

slug.description: Canonical document slug to fetch (e.g. auth/row-level-security)

document--parse_document.description: Parse and extract content from documents (first 50 pages). Handles PDFs, Word docs, PowerPoint, Excel, MP3 and many other formats. Preserves document structure, tables, extracts images, and performs OCR on embedded images.

file_path.description: The path to the document file to parse

imagegen--generate_image.description:
Generates an image based on a text prompt and saves it to the specified file path. Use the best models for large images that are really important. Make sure that you consider aspect ratio given the location of the image on the page when selecting dimensions.

For small images (less than 1000px), use flux.schnell, it's much faster and really good! This should be your default model.
When you generate large images like a fullscreen image, use flux.dev. The maximum resolution is 1920x1920.
Once generated, you MUST import the images in code as ES6 imports.

Prompting tips:
- Mentioning the aspect ratio in the prompt will help the model generate the image with the correct dimensions. For example: "A 16:9 aspect ratio image of a sunset over a calm ocean."
- Use the "Ultra high resolution" suffix to your prompts to maximize image quality.
- If you for example are generating a hero image, mention it in the prompt. Example: "A hero image of a sunset over a calm ocean."

Example:
import heroImage from "@/assets/hero-image.jpg";

IMPORTANT: 
- Dimensions must be between 512 and 1920 pixels and multiples of 32.
- Make sure to not replace images that users have uploaded by generated images unless they explicitly ask for it.

model.description: The model to use for generation. Options: flux.schnell (default), flux.dev. flux.dev generates higher quality images but is slower. Always use flux.schnell unless you're generating a large image like a hero image or fullscreen banner, of if the user asks for high quality.

prompt.description: Text description of the desired image

target_path.description: The file path where the generated image should be saved. Prefer to put them in the 'src/assets' folder.

imagegen--edit_image.description:
Edits or merges existing images based on a text prompt.

This tool can work with single or multiple images:
- Single image: Apply AI-powered edits based on your prompt
- Multiple images: Merge/combine images according to your prompt

Example prompts for single image:
- "make it rainy"
- "change to sunset lighting"
- "add snow"
- "make it more colorful"

Example prompts for multiple images:
- "blend these two landscapes seamlessly"
- "combine the foreground of the first image with the background of the second"
- "merge these portraits into a group photo"
- "create a collage from these images"


This tool is great for object or character consistency. You can reuse the same image and place it in different scenes for example. If users ask to tweak an existing image, use this tool rather than generating a new image.

image_paths.description: Array of paths to existing image files. For single image editing, provide one path. For merging/combining multiple images, provide multiple paths.

prompt.description: Text description of how to edit/merge the image(s). For multiple images, describe how they should be combined.

target_path.description: The file path where the edited/merged image should be saved.

websearch--web_search.description:
Performs a web search and returns relevant results with text content.
Use this to find current information, documentation, or any web-based content.
You can optionally ask for links or image links to be returned as well.
You can also optionally specify a category of search results to return.
Valid categories are (you must use the exact string):
- "news"
- "linkedin profile"
- "pdf"
- "github"
- "personal site"
- "financial report"

There are no other categories. If you don't specify a category, the search will be general.

When to use?
- When you don't have any information about what the user is asking for.
- When you need to find current information, documentation, or any web-based content.
- When you need to find specific technical information, etc.
- When you need to find information about a specific person, company, or organization.
- When you need to find information about a specific event, product, or service.
- When you need to find real (not AI generated) images about a specific person, company, or organization.

** Search guidelines **

You can filter results to specific domains using "site:domain.com" in your query.
You can specify multiple domains: "site:docs.anthropic.com site:github.com API documentation" will search on both domains.
You can search for exact phrases by putting them in double quotes: '"gpt5" model name OAI' will include "gpt5" in the search.
You can exclude specific words by prefixing them with minus: jaguar speed -car will exclude "car" from the search.
For technical information, the following sources are especially useful: stackoverflow, github, official docs of the product, framework, or service.
Account for "Current date" in your responses. For example, if you instructions say "Current date: 2025-07-01", and the user wants the latest docs, do
not use 2024 in the search query. Use 2025!

category.description: Category of search results to return

imageLinks.description: Number of image links to return for each result

links.description: Number of links to return for each result

numResults.description: Number of search results to return (default: 5)

analytics--read_project_analytics.description:
Read the analytics for the production build of the project between two dates, with a given granularity. The granularity can be 'hourly' or 'daily'. The start and end dates must be in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
The start and end dates should be in RFC3339 format or date only format (YYYY-MM-DD).

When to use this tool:
- When the user is asking for usage of their app
- When users want to improve their productions apps

stripe--enable_stripe.description: Enable the Stripe integration on the current project. Calling this tool will prompt the user for their Stripe secret key.

security--run_security_scan.description: Perform comprehensive security analysis of the Supabase backend to detect exposed data, missing RLS policies, and security misconfigurations

security--get_security_scan_results.description: Fetch security information about the project that the user has access to. Set force=true to get results even if a scan is running.

security--get_table_schema.description: Get the database table schema information and security analysis prompt for the project's Supabase database
